results.title: Fred's Films. 'Tis Christmas
results.brief_description: Captured here by Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm home movie maker are highlights of a Melbourne family during the mid 1960s. Christmas for Fred included showing the trains of Flinders St and a W-Class Tram in the City of Melbourne, along with the famous ‘Foy’s Corner’, corner of Bourke and Swanston St. There are some amusements in the gardens and some ‘Viking’ boats rowing on the Yarra. A Santa in the back of a truck can only mean the office Christmas party. The family relax at a swimming pool and have a picnic in a bush setting. Back to a brief sequence of a helicopter landing on the helipad on the Yarra River, then there is a road trip. This features some impressive footage from the camera mounted on the car, to the Mornington Peninsula and Rosebud. Fred and the family relax staying at a caravan park at the beach, go water skiing, spend time in paddle boats and sand dune frolicking. A highlight is the joy flight taken over the area. Returning to the city, the family enjoy a sunny day at ‘Luna Park’ with the wonderful rides and amusements on offer. Fred’s camera work on the ‘Scenic Railway’ in particular, shows his steady hand.

Fred's Films. The Train that refused to die: Puffing Billy

results.title: Fred's Films. ARC Cement Works Geelong [excerpt]
results.brief_description: The A.R.C Cement Works, Geelong, in the early 1960s is faithfully captured here by Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm home movie maker. Fred has recorded a moment in industry that - post 2000 - no longer exists, that of the use of powerful steam locomotives. With the ‘loco’ pulling people on this occasion and not cement, this is most likely a farewell celebration to the use of the engines at the Plant. Fred’s titles tell us it is “3ft 6 Gauge” and there is a close up on an engine name-plate indicating this engine had come all the way from Manchester and another “1903 Leeds, Hudswell Clarke & Co Ltd No. 646”, a smaller black engine that had obviously been a working machine at the Cement Works for many a year. There is a sense of this being quite an occasion with many people visiting to take pictures and enjoy the plumes of steam from these majestic work horses.

results.title: Fred's Films. Stepping South: Apollo Bay Jan 1963
results.brief_description:
It’s summer 1963, time to pack up the car and head to the beach. Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm home movie maker, follows his family’s trip to the beaches of Apollo Bay, the lush rain forest of Paradise and the powerful beauty of the Twelve Apostles.
Along the way we also see Lorne, Port Campbell and Cinema Point in the Otway Ranges.

results.title: Fred's Films. Our Family [excerpt]
results.brief_description: Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm home movie maker, follows his family’s trip into the City of Melbourne. Starting out at St. Kilda Road, they go on into town to sample coffee and sandwiches al fresco-style before journeying on to an exciting game of Australian Rules football at the MCG (Geelong vs. Hawthorn Grand Final 1963). The family meanders around the fountain at the Southern Cross hotel and ventures to Cook’s Cottage in the picturesque Fitzroy Gardens. They finish up the relaxing day with a cold beverage in the beer garden of the Chevron Hotel.

results.title: Caulfield: a Living City
results.creator_credit: John Freney-Mills, Ewart Wade, Caulfield City Council and Caulfield Film Society
results.brief_description:
Weekend activities in the City of Caulfield. Schools, churches, sporting and social service groups keep the city alive at weekends. Activities include the running of the Caulfield Cup, and quieter games such as tennis and bowls. School children learn road safety at special classes and attend the Youth Centre. For the elderly citizens there are “meals-on-wheels”.

(11/2/19 CC) Selected highlights list from MP:

00:00:32:00 Caulfield train station
00:01:07:00 Caulfield Race Course on Caulfield Cup

00:04:35:00 Caulfield Park Bowling Club with men playing bowls and women playing croquet at 00:04:56:00
00:05:20:00 Caulfield Central RSL
00:05:50:00 cricket game on H.G Ritchie Oval
00:06:12:00 15th Caulfield Somers Country scouts packing glass bottles into a 1950’s Holden Ute

00:07:02:00 City of Caulfield Memorial Youth Centre with basketball being played and wrestling with up and coming star Don Fitzpatrick
00:08:00:00 Women sewing at the Caulfield Memorial Youth Centre
00:08:38:00 Curraweena homes near Caulfield community hall

00:12:24:00 what appears to be St Aloysius Church with spire
00:12:44:00 Caulfield Park Conservatory and gardens

00:14:52:00 shot of Caulfield Technical College now Monash University (Caulfield campus) and students entering the front stair case

results.title: Telephone technique
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau, Wesley Greene and Crawley Films
results.brief_description: Part of a series on sales training, this episode deals with telephone training for retail sales clerks. It emphasizes good telephone manners, wide knowledge of stock, importance of correct customer name and address and the necessity for an intelligent descriptive vocabulary when speaking of merchandise over the telephone.

results.title: How to keep a job
results.brief_description: Discusses the habits and attitudes that make for job success once the job is obtained. A man seeking a new job after being fired at his last job is interviewed by the Personnel director of a company and is told that employers want men who are dependable, willing to work, co-operate, loyal and possess initiative.

results.title: A Half million teenagers
results.brief_description: Studies the physiology aspects of venereal disease. Uses animation to show how the organisms of gonorrhea and syphilis enter and affect the body and how the diseases may be recognised. Stresses the need for treatment, pointing out that there is a cure for both diseases.

results.title: Beyond LSD: a film for concerned adults and teenagers
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford, Paul Burnford Film Productions and Film Associates

video_links.name: Beyond LSD: a film for concerned adults and teenagers

results.brief_description: This 1960’s film is about the communication gap between two generations: teenagers and young adults on the one hand, and the generation of those over thirty - “the establishment”. The teenagers’ use of LSD and other drugs is only one of the symptoms of this communication gap. A group of parents desperately seek help in order to understand what has gone wrong. The film is an attempt to go “beyond LSD” and is intended to stimulate discussion amongst high school students, college students, teachers and parents. Ample involuntary hilarity can result from viewing this great hysterical/historical document. Starting as a raucous celluloid freak-out, the film presents its square’s-eye view of the “Generation Gap” through the fictive device of a round table of pod people, each alike in their helmet-hair and cat’s eye glasses. The production crew of this film was primarily made up of teenagers and young adults. Music by ‘The Stayns.’ A minor masterpiece of psychedelic cinema.
